moves.1. e4: Hi everyone, after a subdued lunch it was time to go back for the final game, this one started out as an Advanced French.
moves.1... e6 2. d4 d5 3. e5: 3. e5 - this move, which puts a cramp on black's centre and prevents Nf6 characterises the Advanced Variation of the French Defence.  Black does get some play for this as you will see.
moves.3... c5: 3. ................... c5 - such as this move, which hits out at the d4 pawn which supports the e5 pawn.  White usually has to tie himself down to defending this pawn as I can pile up on it with Nc6.
moves.4. Bb5+ Bd7 5. Bxd7+ Qxd7: 5. ................ Qxd7 - a rather unusual variant of the Advance French as one pair of bishops is exchanged.
moves.6. c3 Nc6 7. Nf3 cxd4 8. cxd4: 8. cxd4 - this pawn exchange is quite common in the Advanced French.
moves.8... Nge7 9. O-O Ng6: 9. .............. Ng6 - must clear the line of Frere Lenoir to enable Henry to castle on the next turn.
moves.10. Nc3 Be7 11. a3 O-O: 11. ............... 0-0 - now my development is complete both players are entering the middle game.
15. Nxg5 - now both dsbs are exchanged.
moves.15... h6 16. Nh3 Nce7: 16. ................. Nce7 - this knight comes over to protect the kingside.
moves.17. b3 b5 18. Rfd1 f6 19. exf6 Rxf6: 19. ...................... Rxf6 - now some cramping is relieved as the e5 pawn disappears from the board.
moves.20. Qg3 Rbf8: 20. ................ Rbf8 - sidestepps the Wicked Witch's attack on the long diagonal and doubles up on the half-open f file.
moves.21. f3 Nf5 22. Qf2 Rc8 23. Rd3: 23. Rd3 - defends the knight on c3.
moves.23... Rc6 24. Na2 a5 25. Qd2 Qc7 26. Rc3: 26. Rc3 - challenges the c file and one pair of rooks is now exchanged.
moves.29. Ne2 Nb7 30. Qc3 Rf7 31. Qc8+ Qxc8 32: 33. ................... Kxf8 - this plethora of exchanges leads myself and Lee into a double knight endgame.
moves.34. Nef4 Nxf4 35. Nxf4: 35. Nxf4 - and now it is down to a single knight ending!
moves.35... Kf7 36. Kf2 Nd8 37. Nd3 Nc6 38. Ke: 39. ................ Kf6 - over the last few moves we have been busily centralising our kings.
moves.40. f4 gxf4+ 41. Nxf4: 41. Nxf4 - white takes back with the knight to avoid a pawn split.  White has a pawn majority on the kingside.
moves.41... a4 42. b4 Ne7 43. Nh5+ Kg6 44. Nf4: 45. .................... Nc6 - I wonder whether Ng6 was a better move here.
moves.46. h4 Ne7 47. g5+ hxg5 48. hxg5+ Kf5: 48. ................Kf5 - if Kxg5 then Nxe6 and then my queenside pawns could fall.
moves.49. Kf3 e5 50. dxe5: 50. dxe5 - here Lee offers me a draw which I accept.  This meant that I scored 3 points out of 5 rounds.  I stayed for the presentation then drove back to Cambridge feeling satisfied with how the second day ended.  Considering that I was out-graded in all five matches 3 points out of 5 is not a bad show.  This has been my most successful congress, although I did manage 3 points out of 6 games in a 30 minutes per side rapidplay in Peterborough the following summer.
